instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, that has no signs of liquid contact, pulls 19.5V from ampmeter, consumes 0.5A at start and stabilizes at 0.27A, has backlight, but no chime and no image (even on external monitor).
I get voltage on vcore coils, and CPU gets hot.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Caps Lock reacts?
Check for USB activity.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Yes, Caps is working and USB activity is ok.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Looks like iGPU got damaged somehow.
Did you try PRAM reset?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi, sorry for the late reply.
Yes, I've tried PRAM but without success. Is there anything else that I can measure to be certain the it is iGPU?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Try new BIOS, just in case.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Tks, I'll do so.
Do you have a CLEAN ME for this model. I can't find it here

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi again,

Sorry for the late reply (a lot of problems to deal with).

It looks that the iGPU its working, because when connected just the board on the bench, without the LCD, it has an image on external monitor. Already tried with a known good lcd and a good lcd cable, but with the same result. With LCD conected it has no image (internal or external monitor). Without internal LCD connected, it has image on external monitor.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Seems that iGPU stops to work properly when PCH detects internal LCD.
I bet for CPU problem...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
